About Myself: I have a very high level of mathematical knowledge up to the post-graduate level. 

These are my main areas of interest:
(1) coding: mainly Python
(2) mathematics up to graduate level and research level
(3) machine learning and artificial intelligence

【26†Nature | 6 min read】

## 【27†A shot of sobriety†gizmodo.com】

Drunk mice sobered up quickly when given a dose of the hormone FGF21. In mice and people, the hormone is produced in the liver, where it helps to process alcohol. Mice that could not produce FGF21 stayed drunk longer than ones that could, and 【27†normal mice given an extra shot of FGF21 after an alcohol binge sobered up an hour and a half faster†gizmodo.com】 than those given a single dose. The hormone could one day be deployed as a treatment for alcohol poisoning, says biochemist and study co-author Steven Kliewer.

【27†Gizmodo | 3 min read†gizmodo.com】

Reference: 【28†Cell Metabolism †doi.org】【28†paper†doi.org】

### Question of the week

For International Women’s Day on Wednesday, 【29†Nature 】【29†spoke to six influential researchers】 about how they are celebrating women in science. We’re asking all readers, too — 【30†please add your thoughts in our poll†survey.alchemer.com】.

## Features & opinion

## 【31†How I honed my leadership skills】

When vaccine-manufacturing specialist Piper Trelstad learnt that her management style wasn’t working for her team members, she felt like she’d been “hit by a truck” — but she was 【31†open with them about her efforts to change her approach】. “I think it is important for leaders to show a level of vulnerability,” she says.

【31†Nature | 6 min read】

## 【32†Futures: Clean-up on Planet 9】

An unsung janitorial crew faces a planet-sized challenge in 【32†the latest short story for 】【32†Nature】【32†’s Futures】 series.

【32†Nature | 4 min read】

## 【33†Podcast: Ozone-shredding wildfires】

Large wildfires could expand and prolong the ozone hole as the smoke reactivates ozone-eating chlorinated chemicals. 【33†Scientists first realized this in the wake of the devastating Australian wildfires in 2019–20】, when the chemistry of the sky above Australia became reminiscent of the Antarctic ozone hole. “It was as big of a wake-up call as I've had in my many years of studying this since the ozone hole was discovered,” atmospheric chemist Susan Solomon tells the Nature Podcast. If wildfires become more frequent with climate change, they could cancel out the hard work that the world has done to ban ozone-damaging chemicals.

【33†Nature Podcast | 27 min listen】

【34†Subscribe to the †podcasts.apple.com】【34†Nature Podcast†podcasts.apple.com】【34† on Apple Podcasts†podcasts.apple.com】, 【35†Google Podcasts†www.google.com】 or 【36†Spotify†open.spotify.com】.

### Quote of the day

## 【37†“Be your quirky, awkward self. Your students will gravitate towards authentic people who care deeply about their success.”】

TikTok’s dancing chemist, André Isaacs, produces fun-loving videos to bond with his students and build an inclusive community. (【37†Nature | 6 min read】)

doi: https://doi.org/10.1038/d41586-023-00765-z 

Today our puzzling penguin Leif Penguinson is hiding in ‘the hall of mosses’ in the lush 【38†Hoh Rain Forest†www.nps.gov】 in Washington. 【39†Can you find the penguin†mcusercontent.com】?

The answer will be in Monday’s e-mail, all thanks to Briefing photo editor and penguin wrangler Tom Houghton.

This newsletter is always evolving — tell us what you think! Please send your feedback to briefing@nature.com.

Flora Graham, senior editor, Nature Briefing 

With contributions by Katrina Krämer and Dyani Lewis 

We’ve recently launched two new e-mails you might like. They’re free, and of course you can unsubscribe at any time.

• 【41†Nature Briefing: Translational Research】 covers biotechnology, drug discovery and pharma. 【41†Sign up here】 to get it free in your inbox each week.

content.text:
The team also proposed an explanation, suggesting that superconductivity could arise from chemical pressure or “stress” caused by introducing copper atoms into lead apatite. Since the arrangement of these introduced impurities is crucial, the team provided a “recipe” for making the material, X-ray diffraction data on its structure and a chemical formula for the final product: Pb 10−x Cu_{x}(PO_{4})_{6}O, where x is the concentration of copper atoms and is between 0.9 and 1.1.

### First replication attempts come up short

Armed with this information, many research groups (and at least one technically-knowledgeable 【66†amateur†twitter.com】 with access to good equipment) began synthesizing their own samples. “The possibilities within the claims of Lee, Kim et al. would be a game-changer for society if they would turn out to be true, so we of course wanted to be part of the history in case of a real breakthrough,” says 【67†Ross Colman†www.mff.cuni.cz】, who participated in a 【68†live online replication attempt†twitter.com】 with colleagues at Charles University in Prague, Czechia.

[Image 1]Superconductivity or bust: The starting materials in the “recipe” for synthesizing LK-99 include lead oxide. (Courtesy: Ross Colman)

Initial experiments did not produce any breakthroughs. In one of the first 【69†reports†arxiv.org】, 【70†V P S Awana†awanavps.webs.com】 and colleagues at India’s 【71†CSIR-National Physical Laboratory†www.nplindia.org】 (NPL) synthesized a sample that became weakly magnetic when placed on a strong magnet, rather than expelling magnetic field like a superconductor would. Another 【72†early replication attempt†arxiv.org】, this one by 【73†Zhiqi Liu†scholar.google.com.sg】 and colleagues at Beihang University in Beijing, China, yielded a sample that behaved like a semiconductor, with a large room-temperature resistance.

Colman says these inconsistencies are partly due to the “messy” nature of the instructions for synthesizing LK-99. “Whilst the synthesis recipe is presented very simply, there are a number of inaccuracies or missing information,” he says. Examples include the dimensions of the equipment used, how the temperature should change during different synthesis stages, and even the fact that the material becomes molten at 925 °C. “A more detailed description would have prevented a lot of guesswork,” he says.

### A door opens a crack…

On the theoretical side, things were slightly more encouraging. A team led by 【74†Xing-Qiu Chen†english.synl.ac.cn】 of China’s Shenyang National Laboratory for Materials Science 【75†calculated†arxiv.org】 that a material with the formula Pb 10−x Cu_{x}(PO_{4})_{6}O would contain electronic structures known as flat bands at the Fermi level, which is the highest energy level that an electron can occupy at 0 K. These flat bands can be a hallmark of superconductivity.

Independently, 【76†Sinéad Griffin†foundry.lbl.gov】, a staff scientist at the Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory in the US, came to a 【77†similar conclusion†arxiv.org】: swapping copper for lead in the appropriate place within Pb 10−x Cu_{x}(PO_{4})_{6}O produces flat bands. Less promisingly, Griffin calculated that an experimentally easier substitution has no such effect. “This result hints to the synthesis challenge in obtaining Cu substituted on the appropriate site,” she wrote.

### …and then slams shut

Despite this caveat, the flat-band results were greeted with elation among LK-99’s growing army of fans on social media. When Griffin 【78†posted her paper on Twitter/X†twitter.com】, accompanied by a “mic drop” GIF featuring former US president Barack Obama, the responses included “This is so badass” and “Incredibly based tweet”.

Over the next fortnight, though, the replication failures continued, and the air began to leak out of the hype bubble. A 【79†second effort†arxiv.org】 by the Indian NPL team used purer precursor materials and produced a sample with X-ray diffraction peaks that more closely matched those in the original arXiv papers. Alas, this new sample was not a superconductor either. It was diamagnetic, becoming magnetized in the opposite direction to the applied field.

[Image 2: Superconductivity]Textbook case: A standard, low-temperature superconducting material levitates above a magnet. (Courtesy: iStock/ktsimage)

This is important, because one of the strongest pieces of evidence in favour of room-temperature superconductivity in LK-99 was the material’s ability to levitate when placed atop a strong magnet under ambient conditions. The Korean team interpreted this as being due to the Meissner effect, but diamagnetic objects (including 【80†frogs and strawberries†www.ru.nl】) will also levitate if the magnetic field is strong enough.

Another 【81†alternative explanation†arxiv.org】 for LK-99’s levitation came from 【82†Shuang Jia†icqm.pku.edu.cn】 and colleagues at Peking University in Beijing. Although they persuaded “some small flaky fragments” of their synthesized sample to levitate, these levitating fragments “ubiquitously contain weak yet definitive soft ferromagnetic components”. Ferromagnetism, they wrote, can explain levitation in LK-99 without recourse to superconductivity.

### A fuller picture emerges

For 【83†Andrei Bernevig†phy.princeton.edu】, a condensed-matter theorist at Princeton University, US, the varying results and associated hype are a source of frustration. “A lot of the stuff early on was rushed and statements from all sides were unchecked,” he tells Physics World. “The social media, memes, etc., have been completely detrimental to progress in this field in my view…I hope we never do science like this again.”

To provide concrete answers, Bernevig and his Princeton colleague 【84†Leslie Schoop†chemistry.princeton.edu】, together with collaborators in Spain, Germany and the University of Oregon, US, focused on a different question. Rather than investigating whether LK-99 exhibited signs of superconductivity, they began by asking: just what is LK-99, anyway?

After synthesizing their own sample, the team performed X-ray diffraction measurements on the best crystal in the batch. This crystal turned out to 【85†contain at least three different components†arxiv.org】. “The

parts:
Recent progress towards room-temperature superconductivity has been marked by both breakthroughs and setbacks. One of the most significant claims came from the research on LK-99, a copper-doped lead apatite, which was initially reported to exhibit superconducting properties at room temperature and ambient pressure. However, subsequent replication attempts have largely failed to confirm these findings. Many research groups synthesized their own samples, but results varied from weak magnetism to behavior characteristic of semiconductors, rather than true superconductors【7†source】【8†source】.

Another promising area of research has been the development of hydrogen-rich superconductors. Some of these materials have shown superconductivity at temperatures above 200 K, which is still below room temperature but significantly higher than traditional superconductors. Researchers continue to explore these compounds, aiming to stabilize them at lower pressures and higher temperatures【7†source】.

Despite these challenges, the quest for room-temperature superconductivity remains a vibrant field of research, driven by the potential revolutionary impact on energy transmission, magnetic levitation, and quantum computing. However, the scientific community remains cautious, emphasizing the need for thorough validation and replication of any new claims【7†source】【8†source】.

【26†Nature | 6 min read】

## 【27†A shot of sobriety†gizmodo.com】

Drunk mice sobered up quickly when given a dose of the hormone FGF21. In mice and people, the hormone is produced in the liver, where it helps to process alcohol. Mice that could not produce FGF21 stayed drunk longer than ones that could, and 【27†normal mice given an extra shot of FGF21 after an alcohol binge sobered up an hour and a half faster†gizmodo.com】 than those given a single dose. The hormone could one day be deployed as a treatment for alcohol poisoning, says biochemist and study co-author Steven Kliewer.

【27†Gizmodo | 3 min read†gizmodo.com】

Reference: 【28†Cell Metabolism †doi.org】【28†paper†doi.org】

### Question of the week

For International Women’s Day on Wednesday, 【29†Nature 】【29†spoke to six influential researchers】 about how they are celebrating women in science. We’re asking all readers, too — 【30†please add your thoughts in our poll†survey.alchemer.com】.

## Features & opinion

## 【31†How I honed my leadership skills】

When vaccine-manufacturing specialist Piper Trelstad learnt that her management style wasn’t working for her team members, she felt like she’d been “hit by a truck” — but she was 【31†open with them about her efforts to change her approach】. “I think it is important for leaders to show a level of vulnerability,” she says.

【31†Nature | 6 min read】

## 【32†Futures: Clean-up on Planet 9】

An unsung janitorial crew faces a planet-sized challenge in 【32†the latest short story for 】【32†Nature】【32†’s Futures】 series.

【32†Nature | 4 min read】

## 【33†Podcast: Ozone-shredding wildfires】

Large wildfires could expand and prolong the ozone hole as the smoke reactivates ozone-eating chlorinated chemicals. 【33†Scientists first realized this in the wake of the devastating Australian wildfires in 2019–20】, when the chemistry of the sky above Australia became reminiscent of the Antarctic ozone hole. “It was as big of a wake-up call as I've had in my many years of studying this since the ozone hole was discovered,” atmospheric chemist Susan Solomon tells the Nature Podcast. If wildfires become more frequent with climate change, they could cancel out the hard work that the world has done to ban ozone-damaging chemicals.

【33†Nature Podcast | 27 min listen】

Mice that could not produce FGF21 stayed drunk longer than ones that could, and 【27†normal mice given an extra shot of FGF21 after an alcohol binge sobered up an hour and a half faster†gizmodo.com】 than those given a single dose. The hormone could one day be deployed as a treatment for alcohol poisoning, says biochemist and study co-author Steven Kliewer.

## 【31†How I honed my leadership skills】

When vaccine-manufacturing specialist Piper Trelstad learnt that her management style wasn’t working for her team members, she felt like she’d been “hit by a truck” — but she was 【31†open with them about her efforts to change her approach】. “I think it is important for leaders to show a level of vulnerability,” she says.

## 【33†Podcast: Ozone-shredding wildfires】

Large wildfires could expand and prolong the ozone hole as the smoke reactivates ozone-eating chlorinated chemicals. 【33†Scientists first realized this in the wake of the devastating Australian wildfires in 2019–20】, when the chemistry of the sky above Australia became reminiscent of the Antarctic ozone hole. “It was as big of a wake-up call as I've had in my many years of studying this since the ozone hole was discovered,” atmospheric chemist Susan Solomon tells the Nature Podcast. If wildfires become more frequent with climate change, they could cancel out the hard work that the world has done to ban ozone-damaging chemicals.

metadata.title: ‘Room-temperature superconductor’ LK-99 fails replication tests – Physics World
metadata.text:
The team also proposed an explanation, suggesting that superconductivity could arise from chemical pressure or “stress” caused by introducing copper atoms into lead apatite. Since the arrangement of these introduced impurities is crucial, the team provided a “recipe” for making the material, X-ray diffraction data on its structure and a chemical formula for the final product: Pb 10−x Cu_{x}(PO_{4})_{6}O, where x is the concentration of copper atoms and is between 0.9 and 1.1.

### First replication attempts come up short

Armed with this information, many research groups (and at least one technically-knowledgeable 【66†amateur†twitter.com】 with access to good equipment) began synthesizing their own samples. “The possibilities within the claims of Lee, Kim et al. would be a game-changer for society if they would turn out to be true, so we of course wanted to be part of the history in case of a real breakthrough,” says 【67†Ross Colman†www.mff.cuni.cz】, who participated in a 【68†live online replication attempt†twitter.com】 with colleagues at Charles University in Prague, Czechia.

[Image 1]Superconductivity or bust: The starting materials in the “recipe” for synthesizing LK-99 include lead oxide. (Courtesy: Ross Colman)

Initial experiments did not produce any breakthroughs. In one of the first 【69†reports†arxiv.org】, 【70†V P S Awana†awanavps.webs.com】 and colleagues at India’s 【71†CSIR-National Physical Laboratory†www.nplindia.org】 (NPL) synthesized a sample that became weakly magnetic when placed on a strong magnet, rather than expelling magnetic field like a superconductor would. Another 【72†early replication attempt†arxiv.org】, this one by 【73†Zhiqi Liu†scholar.google.com.sg】 and colleagues at Beihang University in Beijing, China, yielded a sample that behaved like a semiconductor, with a large room-temperature resistance.

Colman says these inconsistencies are partly due to the “messy” nature of the instructions for synthesizing LK-99. “Whilst the synthesis recipe is presented very simply, there are a number of inaccuracies or missing information,” he says. Examples include the dimensions of the equipment used, how the temperature should change during different synthesis stages, and even the fact that the material becomes molten at 925 °C. “A more detailed description would have prevented a lot of guesswork,” he says.

### A door opens a crack…

On the theoretical side, things were slightly more encouraging. A team led by 【74†Xing-Qiu Chen†english.synl.ac.cn】 of China’s Shenyang National Laboratory for Materials Science 【75†calculated†arxiv.org】 that a material with the formula Pb 10−x Cu_{x}(PO_{4})_{6}O would contain electronic structures known as flat bands at the Fermi level, which is the highest energy level that an electron can occupy at 0 K. These flat bands can be a hallmark of superconductivity.

Independently, 【76†Sinéad Griffin†foundry.lbl.gov】, a staff scientist at the Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory in the US, came to a 【77†similar conclusion†arxiv.org】: swapping copper for lead in the appropriate place within Pb 10−x Cu_{x}(PO_{4})_{6}O produces flat bands. Less promisingly, Griffin calculated that an experimentally easier substitution has no such effect. “This result hints to the synthesis challenge in obtaining Cu substituted on the appropriate site,” she wrote.

### …and then slams shut

Despite this caveat, the flat-band results were greeted with elation among LK-99’s growing army of fans on social media. When Griffin 【78†posted her paper on Twitter/X†twitter.com】, accompanied by a “mic drop” GIF featuring former US president Barack Obama, the responses included “This is so badass” and “Incredibly based tweet”.

Over the next fortnight, though, the replication failures continued, and the air began to leak out of the hype bubble. A 【79†second effort†arxiv.org】 by the Indian NPL team used purer precursor materials and produced a sample with X-ray diffraction peaks that more closely matched those in the original arXiv papers. Alas, this new sample was not a superconductor either. It was diamagnetic, becoming magnetized in the opposite direction to the applied field.

[Image 2: Superconductivity]Textbook case: A standard, low-temperature superconducting material levitates above a magnet. (Courtesy: iStock/ktsimage)

This is important, because one of the strongest pieces of evidence in favour of room-temperature superconductivity in LK-99 was the material’s ability to levitate when placed atop a strong magnet under ambient conditions. The Korean team interpreted this as being due to the Meissner effect, but diamagnetic objects (including 【80†frogs and strawberries†www.ru.nl】) will also levitate if the magnetic field is strong enough.

Another 【81†alternative explanation†arxiv.org】 for LK-99’s levitation came from 【82†Shuang Jia†icqm.pku.edu.cn】 and colleagues at Peking University in Beijing. Although they persuaded “some small flaky fragments” of their synthesized sample to levitate, these levitating fragments “ubiquitously contain weak yet definitive soft ferromagnetic components”. Ferromagnetism, they wrote, can explain levitation in LK-99 without recourse to superconductivity.

### A fuller picture emerges

For 【83†Andrei Bernevig†phy.princeton.edu】, a condensed-matter theorist at Princeton University, US, the varying results and associated hype are a source of frustration. “A lot of the stuff early on was rushed and statements from all sides were unchecked,” he tells Physics World. “The social media, memes, etc., have been completely detrimental to progress in this field in my view…I hope we never do science like this again.”

To provide concrete answers, Bernevig and his Princeton colleague 【84†Leslie Schoop†chemistry.princeton.edu】, together with collaborators in Spain, Germany and the University of Oregon, US, focused on a different question. Rather than investigating whether LK-99 exhibited signs of superconductivity, they began by asking: just what is LK-99, anyway?

After synthesizing their own sample, the team performed X-ray diffraction measurements on the best crystal in the batch. This crystal turned out to 【85†contain at least three different components†arxiv.org】. “The

When Griffin 【78†posted her paper on Twitter/X†twitter.com】, accompanied by a “mic drop” GIF featuring former US president Barack Obama, the responses included “This is so badass” and “Incredibly based tweet”.

Over the next fortnight, though, the replication failures continued, and the air began to leak out of the hype bubble. A 【79†second effort†arxiv.org】 by the Indian NPL team used purer precursor materials and produced a sample with X-ray diffraction peaks that more closely matched those in the original arXiv papers. Alas, this new sample was not a superconductor either. It was diamagnetic, becoming magnetized in the opposite direction to the applied field.

[Image 2: Superconductivity]Textbook case: A standard, low-temperature superconducting material levitates above a magnet. (Courtesy: iStock/ktsimage)

This is important, because one of the strongest pieces of evidence in favour of room-temperature superconductivity in LK-99 was the material’s ability to levitate when placed atop a strong magnet under ambient conditions. The Korean team interpreted this as being due to the Meissner effect, but diamagnetic objects (including 【80†frogs and strawberries†www.ru.nl】) will also levitate if the magnetic field is strong enough.

Another 【81†alternative explanation†arxiv.org】 for LK-99’s levitation came from 【82†Shuang Jia†icqm.pku.edu.cn】 and colleagues at Peking University in Beijing. Although they persuaded “some small flaky fragments” of their synthesized sample to levitate, these levitating fragments “ubiquitously contain weak yet definitive soft ferromagnetic components”. Ferromagnetism, they wrote, can explain levitation in LK-99 without recourse to superconductivity.

For 【83†Andrei Bernevig†phy.princeton.edu】, a condensed-matter theorist at Princeton University, US, the varying results and associated hype are a source of frustration. “A lot of the stuff early on was rushed and statements from all sides were unchecked,” he tells Physics World. “The social media, memes, etc., have been completely detrimental to progress in this field in my view…I hope we never do science like this again.”

Rather than investigating whether LK-99 exhibited signs of superconductivity, they began by asking: just what is LK-99, anyway?

## 【27†A shot of sobriety†gizmodo.com】

Drunk mice sobered up quickly when given a dose of the hormone FGF21. In mice and people, the hormone is produced in the liver, where it helps to process alcohol. Mice that could not produce FGF21 stayed drunk longer than ones that could, and 【27†normal mice given an extra shot of FGF21 after an alcohol binge sobered up an hour and a half faster†gizmodo.com】 than those given a single dose. The hormone could one day be deployed as a treatment for alcohol poisoning, says biochemist and study co-author Steven Kliewer.

When vaccine-manufacturing specialist Piper Trelstad learnt that her management style wasn’t working for her team members, she felt like she’d been “hit by a truck” — but she was 【31†open with them about her efforts to change her approach】. “I think it is important for leaders to show a level of vulnerability,” she says.

## 【33†Podcast: Ozone-shredding wildfires】

Large wildfires could expand and prolong the ozone hole as the smoke reactivates ozone-eating chlorinated chemicals. 【33†Scientists first realized this in the wake of the devastating Australian wildfires in 2019–20】, when the chemistry of the sky above Australia became reminiscent of the Antarctic ozone hole. “It was as big of a wake-up call as I've had in my many years of studying this since the ozone hole was discovered,” atmospheric chemist Susan Solomon tells the Nature Podcast. If wildfires become more frequent with climate change, they could cancel out the hard work that the world has done to ban ozone-damaging chemicals.

The team also proposed an explanation, suggesting that superconductivity could arise from chemical pressure or “stress” caused by introducing copper atoms into lead apatite. Since the arrangement of these introduced impurities is crucial, the team provided a “recipe” for making the material, X-ray diffraction data on its structure and a chemical formula for the final product: Pb 10−x Cu_{x}(PO_{4})_{6}O, where x is the concentration of copper atoms and is between 0.9 and 1.1.

### First replication attempts come up short

Armed with this information, many research groups (and at least one technically-knowledgeable 【66†amateur†twitter.com】 with access to good equipment) began synthesizing their own samples. “The possibilities within the claims of Lee, Kim et al. would be a game-changer for society if they would turn out to be true, so we of course wanted to be part of the history in case of a real breakthrough,” says 【67†Ross Colman†www.mff.cuni.cz】, who participated in a 【68†live online replication attempt†twitter.com】 with colleagues at Charles University in Prague, Czechia.

[Image 1]Superconductivity or bust: The starting materials in the “recipe” for synthesizing LK-99 include lead oxide. (Courtesy: Ross Colman)

Initial experiments did not produce any breakthroughs. In one of the first 【69†reports†arxiv.org】, 【70†V P S Awana†awanavps.webs.com】 and colleagues at India’s 【71†CSIR-National Physical Laboratory†www.nplindia.org】 (NPL) synthesized a sample that became weakly magnetic when placed on a strong magnet, rather than expelling magnetic field like a superconductor would. Another 【72†early replication attempt†arxiv.org】, this one by 【73†Zhiqi Liu†scholar.google.com.sg】 and colleagues at Beihang University in Beijing, China, yielded a sample that behaved like a semiconductor, with a large room-temperature resistance.

Colman says these inconsistencies are partly due to the “messy” nature of the instructions for synthesizing LK-99. “Whilst the synthesis recipe is presented very simply, there are a number of inaccuracies or missing information,” he says. Examples include the dimensions of the equipment used, how the temperature should change during different synthesis stages, and even the fact that the material becomes molten at 925 °C. “A more detailed description would have prevented a lot of guesswork,” he says.

### A door opens a crack…

On the theoretical side, things were slightly more encouraging. A team led by 【74†Xing-Qiu Chen†english.synl.ac.cn】 of China’s Shenyang National Laboratory for Materials Science 【75†calculated†arxiv.org】 that a material with the formula Pb 10−x Cu_{x}(PO_{4})_{6}O would contain electronic structures known as flat bands at the Fermi level, which is the highest energy level that an electron can occupy at 0 K. These flat bands can be a hallmark of superconductivity.

Independently, 【76†Sinéad Griffin†foundry.lbl.gov】, a staff scientist at the Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory in the US, came to a 【77†similar conclusion†arxiv.org】: swapping copper for lead in the appropriate place within Pb 10−x Cu_{x}(PO_{4})_{6}O produces flat bands. Less promisingly, Griffin calculated that an experimentally easier substitution has no such effect. “This result hints to the synthesis challenge in obtaining Cu substituted on the appropriate site,” she wrote.

### …and then slams shut

Despite this caveat, the flat-band results were greeted with elation among LK-99’s growing army of fans on social media. When Griffin 【78†posted her paper on Twitter/X†twitter.com】, accompanied by a “mic drop” GIF featuring former US president Barack Obama, the responses included “This is so badass” and “Incredibly based tweet”.

Over the next fortnight, though, the replication failures continued, and the air began to leak out of the hype bubble. A 【79†second effort†arxiv.org】 by the Indian NPL team used purer precursor materials and produced a sample with X-ray diffraction peaks that more closely matched those in the original arXiv papers. Alas, this new sample was not a superconductor either. It was diamagnetic, becoming magnetized in the opposite direction to the applied field.

parts: What are the main technological and scientific hurdles that must be overcome?

Achieving room-temperature superconductivity faces several significant technological and scientific hurdles:

1. **Material Stability**:
   - **Hydrogen-Rich Compounds**: Many promising superconductors require extremely high pressures to remain stable, such as hydrogen sulfide, which becomes superconducting at around 203 K but under pressures above 150 GPa. Developing materials that are stable at ambient pressures while maintaining superconducting properties is a major challenge【7†source】.

2. **Synthesis and Reproducibility**:
   - **Consistency**: The synthesis of new superconducting materials often results in inconsistencies. For example, LK-99’s replication attempts failed due to "messy" instructions and the sensitive nature of the synthesis process, leading to different results across various laboratories【8†source】.

3. **Understanding Mechanisms**:
   - **Electronic Structure**: A detailed understanding of the electronic mechanisms that lead to superconductivity at higher temperatures is still developing. Theoretical models, such as those involving "flat bands" at the Fermi level, provide insights but require experimental validation and refinement【8†source】.

4. **Measurement and Verification**:
   - **Experimental Validation**: Differentiating true superconductivity from other effects like ferromagnetism or diamagnetism is crucial. For instance, some samples showed levitation due to ferromagnetic impurities rather than the Meissner effect, which is definitive for superconductivity【8†source】.

5. **Material Properties**:
   - **Impurity Control**: The presence of impurities can significantly affect superconducting properties. Controlling the purity and composition of materials is essential for consistent results and understanding the properties of the superconductors【8†source】.

6. **Scalability**:
   - **Industrial Application**: For superconductors to be practical for industrial applications, they must be scalable. This involves not only synthesizing the material but also integrating it into existing technologies and systems, which often requires overcoming additional engineering challenges【7†source】【8†source】.

Overcoming these hurdles requires interdisciplinary efforts combining materials science, physics, chemistry, and engineering. Continuous research and collaboration are essential to make meaningful progress towards practical room-temperature superconductors.

metadata.title: ‘Room-temperature superconductor’ LK-99 fails replication tests – Physics World
metadata.text:
The team also proposed an explanation, suggesting that superconductivity could arise from chemical pressure or “stress” caused by introducing copper atoms into lead apatite. Since the arrangement of these introduced impurities is crucial, the team provided a “recipe” for making the material, X-ray diffraction data on its structure and a chemical formula for the final product: Pb 10−x Cu_{x}(PO_{4})_{6}O, where x is the concentration of copper atoms and is between 0.9 and 1.1.

### First replication attempts come up short

Armed with this information, many research groups (and at least one technically-knowledgeable 【66†amateur†twitter.com】 with access to good equipment) began synthesizing their own samples. “The possibilities within the claims of Lee, Kim et al. would be a game-changer for society if they would turn out to be true, so we of course wanted to be part of the history in case of a real breakthrough,” says 【67†Ross Colman†www.mff.cuni.cz】, who participated in a 【68†live online replication attempt†twitter.com】 with colleagues at Charles University in Prague, Czechia.

[Image 1]Superconductivity or bust: The starting materials in the “recipe” for synthesizing LK-99 include lead oxide. (Courtesy: Ross Colman)

Initial experiments did not produce any breakthroughs. In one of the first 【69†reports†arxiv.org】, 【70†V P S Awana†awanavps.webs.com】 and colleagues at India’s 【71†CSIR-National Physical Laboratory†www.nplindia.org】 (NPL) synthesized a sample that became weakly magnetic when placed on a strong magnet, rather than expelling magnetic field like a superconductor would. Another 【72†early replication attempt†arxiv.org】, this one by 【73†Zhiqi Liu†scholar.google.com.sg】 and colleagues at Beihang University in Beijing, China, yielded a sample that behaved like a semiconductor, with a large room-temperature resistance.

Colman says these inconsistencies are partly due to the “messy” nature of the instructions for synthesizing LK-99. “Whilst the synthesis recipe is presented very simply, there are a number of inaccuracies or missing information,” he says. Examples include the dimensions of the equipment used, how the temperature should change during different synthesis stages, and even the fact that the material becomes molten at 925 °C. “A more detailed description would have prevented a lot of guesswork,” he says.

### A door opens a crack…

On the theoretical side, things were slightly more encouraging. A team led by 【74†Xing-Qiu Chen†english.synl.ac.cn】 of China’s Shenyang National Laboratory for Materials Science 【75†calculated†arxiv.org】 that a material with the formula Pb 10−x Cu_{x}(PO_{4})_{6}O would contain electronic structures known as flat bands at the Fermi level, which is the highest energy level that an electron can occupy at 0 K. These flat bands can be a hallmark of superconductivity.

Independently, 【76†Sinéad Griffin†foundry.lbl.gov】, a staff scientist at the Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory in the US, came to a 【77†similar conclusion†arxiv.org】: swapping copper for lead in the appropriate place within Pb 10−x Cu_{x}(PO_{4})_{6}O produces flat bands. Less promisingly, Griffin calculated that an experimentally easier substitution has no such effect. “This result hints to the synthesis challenge in obtaining Cu substituted on the appropriate site,” she wrote.

### …and then slams shut

Despite this caveat, the flat-band results were greeted with elation among LK-99’s growing army of fans on social media. When Griffin 【78†posted her paper on Twitter/X†twitter.com】, accompanied by a “mic drop” GIF featuring former US president Barack Obama, the responses included “This is so badass” and “Incredibly based tweet”.

Over the next fortnight, though, the replication failures continued, and the air began to leak out of the hype bubble. A 【79†second effort†arxiv.org】 by the Indian NPL team used purer precursor materials and produced a sample with X-ray diffraction peaks that more closely matched those in the original arXiv papers. Alas, this new sample was not a superconductor either. It was diamagnetic, becoming magnetized in the opposite direction to the applied field.

[Image 2: Superconductivity]Textbook case: A standard, low-temperature superconducting material levitates above a magnet. (Courtesy: iStock/ktsimage)

This is important, because one of the strongest pieces of evidence in favour of room-temperature superconductivity in LK-99 was the material’s ability to levitate when placed atop a strong magnet under ambient conditions. The Korean team interpreted this as being due to the Meissner effect, but diamagnetic objects (including 【80†frogs and strawberries†www.ru.nl】) will also levitate if the magnetic field is strong enough.

Another 【81†alternative explanation†arxiv.org】 for LK-99’s levitation came from 【82†Shuang Jia†icqm.pku.edu.cn】 and colleagues at Peking University in Beijing. Although they persuaded “some small flaky fragments” of their synthesized sample to levitate, these levitating fragments “ubiquitously contain weak yet definitive soft ferromagnetic components”. Ferromagnetism, they wrote, can explain levitation in LK-99 without recourse to superconductivity.

### A fuller picture emerges

For 【83†Andrei Bernevig†phy.princeton.edu】, a condensed-matter theorist at Princeton University, US, the varying results and associated hype are a source of frustration. “A lot of the stuff early on was rushed and statements from all sides were unchecked,” he tells Physics World. “The social media, memes, etc., have been completely detrimental to progress in this field in my view…I hope we never do science like this again.”

To provide concrete answers, Bernevig and his Princeton colleague 【84†Leslie Schoop†chemistry.princeton.edu】, together with collaborators in Spain, Germany and the University of Oregon, US, focused on a different question. Rather than investigating whether LK-99 exhibited signs of superconductivity, they began by asking: just what is LK-99, anyway?

After synthesizing their own sample, the team performed X-ray diffraction measurements on the best crystal in the batch. This crystal turned out to 【85†contain at least three different components†arxiv.org】. “The

## 【27†A shot of sobriety†gizmodo.com】

Drunk mice sobered up quickly when given a dose of the hormone FGF21. In mice and people, the hormone is produced in the liver, where it helps to process alcohol. Mice that could not produce FGF21 stayed drunk longer than ones that could, and 【27†normal mice given an extra shot of FGF21 after an alcohol binge sobered up an hour and a half faster†gizmodo.com】 than those given a single dose. The hormone could one day be deployed as a treatment for alcohol poisoning, says biochemist and study co-author Steven Kliewer.

【27†Gizmodo | 3 min read†gizmodo.com】

Reference: 【28†Cell Metabolism †doi.org】【28†paper†doi.org】

### Question of the week

For International Women’s Day on Wednesday, 【29†Nature 】【29†spoke to six influential researchers】 about how they are celebrating women in science. We’re asking all readers, too — 【30†please add your thoughts in our poll†survey.alchemer.com】.

## Features & opinion

## 【31†How I honed my leadership skills】

When vaccine-manufacturing specialist Piper Trelstad learnt that her management style wasn’t working for her team members, she felt like she’d been “hit by a truck” — but she was 【31†open with them about her efforts to change her approach】. “I think it is important for leaders to show a level of vulnerability,” she says.

【31†Nature | 6 min read】

## 【32†Futures: Clean-up on Planet 9】

An unsung janitorial crew faces a planet-sized challenge in 【32†the latest short story for 】【32†Nature】【32†’s Futures】 series.

【32†Nature | 4 min read】

## 【33†Podcast: Ozone-shredding wildfires】

Large wildfires could expand and prolong the ozone hole as the smoke reactivates ozone-eating chlorinated chemicals. 【33†Scientists first realized this in the wake of the devastating Australian wildfires in 2019–20】, when the chemistry of the sky above Australia became reminiscent of the Antarctic ozone hole. “It was as big of a wake-up call as I've had in my many years of studying this since the ozone hole was discovered,” atmospheric chemist Susan Solomon tells the Nature Podcast. If wildfires become more frequent with climate change, they could cancel out the hard work that the world has done to ban ozone-damaging chemicals.

【33†Nature Podcast | 27 min listen】

【34†Subscribe to the †podcasts.apple.com】【34†Nature Podcast†podcasts.apple.com】【34† on Apple Podcasts†podcasts.apple.com】, 【35†Google Podcasts†www.google.com】 or 【36†Spotify†open.spotify.com】.

### Quote of the day

## 【37†“Be your quirky, awkward self. Your students will gravitate towards authentic people who care deeply about their success.”】

TikTok’s dancing chemist, André Isaacs, produces fun-loving videos to bond with his students and build an inclusive community. (【37†Nature | 6 min read】)

doi: https://doi.org/10.1038/d41586-023-00765-z 

Today our puzzling penguin Leif Penguinson is hiding in ‘the hall of mosses’ in the lush 【38†Hoh Rain Forest†www.nps.gov】 in Washington. 【39†Can you find the penguin†mcusercontent.com】?

The answer will be in Monday’s e-mail, all thanks to Briefing photo editor and penguin wrangler Tom Houghton.

metadata.title: ‘Room-temperature superconductor’ LK-99 fails replication tests – Physics World
metadata.text:
The team also proposed an explanation, suggesting that superconductivity could arise from chemical pressure or “stress” caused by introducing copper atoms into lead apatite. Since the arrangement of these introduced impurities is crucial, the team provided a “recipe” for making the material, X-ray diffraction data on its structure and a chemical formula for the final product: Pb 10−x Cu_{x}(PO_{4})_{6}O, where x is the concentration of copper atoms and is between 0.9 and 1.1.

### First replication attempts come up short

Armed with this information, many research groups (and at least one technically-knowledgeable 【66†amateur†twitter.com】 with access to good equipment) began synthesizing their own samples. “The possibilities within the claims of Lee, Kim et al. would be a game-changer for society if they would turn out to be true, so we of course wanted to be part of the history in case of a real breakthrough,” says 【67†Ross Colman†www.mff.cuni.cz】, who participated in a 【68†live online replication attempt†twitter.com】 with colleagues at Charles University in Prague, Czechia.

[Image 1]Superconductivity or bust: The starting materials in the “recipe” for synthesizing LK-99 include lead oxide. (Courtesy: Ross Colman)

Initial experiments did not produce any breakthroughs. In one of the first 【69†reports†arxiv.org】, 【70†V P S Awana†awanavps.webs.com】 and colleagues at India’s 【71†CSIR-National Physical Laboratory†www.nplindia.org】 (NPL) synthesized a sample that became weakly magnetic when placed on a strong magnet, rather than expelling magnetic field like a superconductor would. Another 【72†early replication attempt†arxiv.org】, this one by 【73†Zhiqi Liu†scholar.google.com.sg】 and colleagues at Beihang University in Beijing, China, yielded a sample that behaved like a semiconductor, with a large room-temperature resistance.

Colman says these inconsistencies are partly due to the “messy” nature of the instructions for synthesizing LK-99. “Whilst the synthesis recipe is presented very simply, there are a number of inaccuracies or missing information,” he says. Examples include the dimensions of the equipment used, how the temperature should change during different synthesis stages, and even the fact that the material becomes molten at 925 °C. “A more detailed description would have prevented a lot of guesswork,” he says.

### A door opens a crack…

On the theoretical side, things were slightly more encouraging. A team led by 【74†Xing-Qiu Chen†english.synl.ac.cn】 of China’s Shenyang National Laboratory for Materials Science 【75†calculated†arxiv.org】 that a material with the formula Pb 10−x Cu_{x}(PO_{4})_{6}O would contain electronic structures known as flat bands at the Fermi level, which is the highest energy level that an electron can occupy at 0 K. These flat bands can be a hallmark of superconductivity.

Independently, 【76†Sinéad Griffin†foundry.lbl.gov】, a staff scientist at the Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory in the US, came to a 【77†similar conclusion†arxiv.org】: swapping copper for lead in the appropriate place within Pb 10−x Cu_{x}(PO_{4})_{6}O produces flat bands. Less promisingly, Griffin calculated that an experimentally easier substitution has no such effect. “This result hints to the synthesis challenge in obtaining Cu substituted on the appropriate site,” she wrote.

### …and then slams shut

Despite this caveat, the flat-band results were greeted with elation among LK-99’s growing army of fans on social media. When Griffin 【78†posted her paper on Twitter/X†twitter.com】, accompanied by a “mic drop” GIF featuring former US president Barack Obama, the responses included “This is so badass” and “Incredibly based tweet”.

Over the next fortnight, though, the replication failures continued, and the air began to leak out of the hype bubble. A 【79†second effort†arxiv.org】 by the Indian NPL team used purer precursor materials and produced a sample with X-ray diffraction peaks that more closely matched those in the original arXiv papers. Alas, this new sample was not a superconductor either. It was diamagnetic, becoming magnetized in the opposite direction to the applied field.

[Image 2: Superconductivity]Textbook case: A standard, low-temperature superconducting material levitates above a magnet. (Courtesy: iStock/ktsimage)

This is important, because one of the strongest pieces of evidence in favour of room-temperature superconductivity in LK-99 was the material’s ability to levitate when placed atop a strong magnet under ambient conditions. The Korean team interpreted this as being due to the Meissner effect, but diamagnetic objects (including 【80†frogs and strawberries†www.ru.nl】) will also levitate if the magnetic field is strong enough.

Another 【81†alternative explanation†arxiv.org】 for LK-99’s levitation came from 【82†Shuang Jia†icqm.pku.edu.cn】 and colleagues at Peking University in Beijing. Although they persuaded “some small flaky fragments” of their synthesized sample to levitate, these levitating fragments “ubiquitously contain weak yet definitive soft ferromagnetic components”. Ferromagnetism, they wrote, can explain levitation in LK-99 without recourse to superconductivity.

### A fuller picture emerges

For 【83†Andrei Bernevig†phy.princeton.edu】, a condensed-matter theorist at Princeton University, US, the varying results and associated hype are a source of frustration. “A lot of the stuff early on was rushed and statements from all sides were unchecked,” he tells Physics World. “The social media, memes, etc., have been completely detrimental to progress in this field in my view…I hope we never do science like this again.”

To provide concrete answers, Bernevig and his Princeton colleague 【84†Leslie Schoop†chemistry.princeton.edu】, together with collaborators in Spain, Germany and the University of Oregon, US, focused on a different question. Rather than investigating whether LK-99 exhibited signs of superconductivity, they began by asking: just what is LK-99, anyway?

After synthesizing their own sample, the team performed X-ray diffraction measurements on the best crystal in the batch. This crystal turned out to 【85†contain at least three different components†arxiv.org】. “The

content_references.title: Daily briefing: Spectacular new claim of room-temperature superconductivity
content_references.snippet:
【26†Nature | 6 min read】

## 【27†A shot of sobriety†gizmodo.com】

Drunk mice sobered up quickly when given a dose of the hormone FGF21. In mice and people, the hormone is produced in the liver, where it helps to process alcohol. Mice that could not produce FGF21 stayed drunk longer than ones that could, and 【27†normal mice given an extra shot of FGF21 after an alcohol binge sobered up an hour and a half faster†gizmodo.com】 than those given a single dose. The hormone could one day be deployed as a treatment for alcohol poisoning, says biochemist and study co-author Steven Kliewer.

【27†Gizmodo | 3 min read†gizmodo.com】

Reference: 【28†Cell Metabolism †doi.org】【28†paper†doi.org】

### Question of the week

For International Women’s Day on Wednesday, 【29†Nature 】【29†spoke to six influential researchers】 about how they are celebrating women in science. We’re asking all readers, too — 【30†please add your thoughts in our poll†survey.alchemer.com】.

## Features & opinion

## 【31†How I honed my leadership skills】

When vaccine-manufacturing specialist Piper Trelstad learnt that her management style wasn’t working for her team members, she felt like she’d been “hit by a truck” — but she was 【31†open with them about her efforts to change her approach】. “I think it is important for leaders to show a level of vulnerability,” she says.

【31†Nature | 6 min read】

## 【32†Futures: Clean-up on Planet 9】

An unsung janitorial crew faces a planet-sized challenge in 【32†the latest short story for 】【32†Nature】【32†’s Futures】 series.

【32†Nature | 4 min read】

## 【33†Podcast: Ozone-shredding wildfires】

Large wildfires could expand and prolong the ozone hole as the smoke reactivates ozone-eating chlorinated chemicals. 【33†Scientists first realized this in the wake of the devastating Australian wildfires in 2019–20】, when the chemistry of the sky above Australia became reminiscent of the Antarctic ozone hole. “It was as big of a wake-up call as I've had in my many years of studying this since the ozone hole was discovered,” atmospheric chemist Susan Solomon tells the Nature Podcast. If wildfires become more frequent with climate change, they could cancel out the hard work that the world has done to ban ozone-damaging chemicals.

【33†Nature Podcast | 27 min listen】

【34†Subscribe to the †podcasts.apple.com】【34†Nature Podcast†podcasts.apple.com】【34† on Apple Podcasts†podcasts.apple.com】, 【35†Google Podcasts†www.google.com】 or 【36†Spotify†open.spotify.com】.

### Quote of the day

## 【37†“Be your quirky, awkward self. Your students will gravitate towards authentic people who care deeply about their success.”】

TikTok’s dancing chemist, André Isaacs, produces fun-loving videos to bond with his students and build an inclusive community. (【37†Nature | 6 min read】)

doi: https://doi.org/10.1038/d41586-023-00765-z 

Today our puzzling penguin Leif Penguinson is hiding in ‘the hall of mosses’ in the lush 【38†Hoh Rain Forest†www.nps.gov】 in Washington. 【39†Can you find the penguin†mcusercontent.com】?

The answer will be in Monday’s e-mail, all thanks to Briefing photo editor and penguin wrangler Tom Houghton.

Despite this caveat, the flat-band results were greeted with elation among LK-99’s growing army of fans on social media. When Griffin 【78†posted her paper on Twitter/X†twitter.com】, accompanied by a “mic drop” GIF featuring former US president Barack Obama, the responses included “This is so badass” and “Incredibly based tweet”.

Over the next fortnight, though, the replication failures continued, and the air began to leak out of the hype bubble. A 【79†second effort†arxiv.org】 by the Indian NPL team used purer precursor materials and produced a sample with X-ray diffraction peaks that more closely matched those in the original arXiv papers. This is important, because one of the strongest pieces of evidence in favour of room-temperature superconductivity in LK-99 was the material’s ability to levitate when placed atop a strong magnet under ambient conditions. The Korean team interpreted this as being due to the Meissner effect, but diamagnetic objects (including 【80†frogs and strawberries†www.ru.nl】) will also levitate if the magnetic field is strong enough.

Although they persuaded “some small flaky fragments” of their synthesized sample to levitate, these levitating fragments “ubiquitously contain weak yet definitive soft ferromagnetic components”. Ferromagnetism, they wrote, can explain levitation in LK-99 without recourse to superconductivity.

To provide concrete answers, Bernevig and his Princeton colleague 【84†Leslie Schoop†chemistry.princeton.edu】, together with collaborators in Spain, Germany and the University of Oregon, US, focused on a different question. Rather than investigating whether LK-99 exhibited signs of superconductivity, they began by asking: just what is LK-99, anyway?

## 【27†A shot of sobriety†gizmodo.com】

Drunk mice sobered up quickly when given a dose of the hormone FGF21. In mice and people, the hormone is produced in the liver, where it helps to process alcohol. Mice that could not produce FGF21 stayed drunk longer than ones that could, and 【27†normal mice given an extra shot of FGF21 after an alcohol binge sobered up an hour and a half faster†gizmodo.com】 than those given a single dose. The hormone could one day be deployed as a treatment for alcohol poisoning, says biochemist and study co-author Steven Kliewer.

【27†Gizmodo | 3 min read†gizmodo.com】

Reference: 【28†Cell Metabolism †doi.org】【28†paper†doi.org】

### Question of the week

For International Women’s Day on Wednesday, 【29†Nature 】【29†spoke to six influential researchers】 about how they are celebrating women in science. We’re asking all readers, too — 【30†please add your thoughts in our poll†survey.alchemer.com】.

## Features & opinion

## 【31†How I honed my leadership skills】

When vaccine-manufacturing specialist Piper Trelstad learnt that her management style wasn’t working for her team members, she felt like she’d been “hit by a truck” — but she was 【31†open with them about her efforts to change her approach】. “I think it is important for leaders to show a level of vulnerability,” she says.

【31†Nature | 6 min read】

## 【32†Futures: Clean-up on Planet 9】

An unsung janitorial crew faces a planet-sized challenge in 【32†the latest short story for 】【32†Nature】【32†’s Futures】 series.

【32†Nature | 4 min read】

## 【33†Podcast: Ozone-shredding wildfires】

Large wildfires could expand and prolong the ozone hole as the smoke reactivates ozone-eating chlorinated chemicals. 【33†Scientists first realized this in the wake of the devastating Australian wildfires in 2019–20】, when the chemistry of the sky above Australia became reminiscent of the Antarctic ozone hole. “It was as big of a wake-up call as I've had in my many years of studying this since the ozone hole was discovered,” atmospheric chemist Susan Solomon tells the Nature Podcast. If wildfires become more frequent with climate change, they could cancel out the hard work that the world has done to ban ozone-damaging chemicals.

【33†Nature Podcast | 27 min listen】

### Quote of the day

## 【37†“Be your quirky, awkward self. Your students will gravitate towards authentic people who care deeply about their success.”】

TikTok’s dancing chemist, André Isaacs, produces fun-loving videos to bond with his students and build an inclusive community. (【37†Nature | 6 min read】)
